content: On September 29, 2006, Congress passed the Department of Defense FY2007 Appropriation bill (H.R. 5631/P.L. 109-289) with a continuing resolution funding Science, State, Justice, and Commerce (SSJC) agencies through November 17, 2006. Subsequent CRs extended funding through December 8, 2006 (H.J.Res. 100) and February 15, 2007 (H.J.Res. 102). P.L. 110-5 amended P.L. 109-289, extending appropriations through FY2007. The House passed its SSJC appropriation bill (H.R. 5672) on June 29, providing $63.1 billion in total funding. This included allocations for the Department of Justice, Department of Commerce, Science agencies, Department of State, and related agencies. The Senate also worked on their version of the bill, recommending funding levels for Justice, Commerce, Science, and related agencies. The Administration submitted its FY2007 budget to Congress on February 6, 2006. The Administration submitted its FY2007 budget to Congress on February 6, 2006, requesting funding for various agencies under different subcommittees. The President signed the FY2006 appropriations bill into law on November 22, 2005, providing funding for the agencies under the Science, State, Justice, Commerce Appropriations subcommittee. The Science, State, Justice, Commerce Appropriations subcommittee of the House oversees appropriations for major departments and agencies, including Department of Justice, Department of Commerce, Department of State, Science, and Related Agencies. Changes in jurisdiction were made in the 109th Congress. In the 109th Congress, jurisdiction for Judiciary appropriations was moved to other subcommittees in both the House and Senate. Science appropriations, including NASA and NSF, were transferred to the CJS subcommittees. The Department of State appropriations were shifted to the Foreign Operations subcommittee in the Senate but remain under SSJC in the House. The Senate Appropriations Committee placed NIST and NOAA under its Title III Science Agencies. The Administration requested $64.2 billion for SSJC and $54.2 billion for CJS in its FY2006 budget. The House and Senate passed the SSJC bill (H.R. 2862) in FY2006 budget request. The Senate also passed the State, Foreign Operations Appropriation bill (H.R. 3057) with a budget of $9,709.2 for the Department of State. The CJS bill was passed by the Senate with a vote of 91-4. The Conference Report (H.Rept. 109-272) was approved by the House and Senate, and signed into law. The Senate approved the CJS appropriations bill on November 11, 2005, by a vote of 94-5, and President Bush signed it into law on November 22, 2005. The FY2006 appropriations included a 1.28% across-the-board rescission. Funding trends over FY2002-FY2006 showed a decrease for the Department of Justice and increases for the Department of Commerce, Title III Science Agencies, and the Department of State. The Justice Department's budget declined in FY2003 due to activities being relocated to the Department of Homeland Security. The Justice Department's budget has continued to be below the FY2002 total, while the Commerce Department's budget has generally increased with a slight decrease in FY2006. The Science Agencies' funding has gradually increased over five years, and the State Department's funding has increased each year through FY2005. The President's FY2007 budget request proposes consolidating various law enforcement grant programs into the Justice Assistance account. Funding for certain Office of Justice Programs (OJP) programs may be eliminated in the FY2007 budget request. The budget request proposes eliminating funding for several OJP programs, including JAG, Discretionary Grants, Indian Country Prison Grants, and Tribal Court Grants. It suggests increasing funding for the Project Safe Neighborhoods initiative to $395 million, which would include various programs to combat firearms-related crime. The FY2007 President's budget proposes funding for expanding and improving Drug Courts, providing $69 million for the program, an increase of $60 million over the FY2006 enacted appropriations. The budget also includes funding of $40 million for the Meth Hot Spots program, aimed at assisting state and local law enforcement in cleaning up toxic waste sites from methamphetamine production. Additionally, the President's request for DEA includes transferring the HIDTA program to DOJ and coordinating it with other antidrug efforts. The budget request proposes $208 million for HIDTA funding in FY2007, part of DEA's comprehensive drug enforcement strategy. Key issues include appropriations measures limiting the use of fees by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office and a proposed shift in funding towards basic research in physical sciences as part of the President's "American Competitiveness Initiative." The Bush Administration has requested an additional $45 million for the National Telecommunications. The Bush Administration has requested $45 million to fund the Digital Television Transition and Public Safety Fund as mandated by the Deficit Reduction Act of 2005. There are deadlines for the FCC to auction unused analog spectrum by 2008 and convert all U.S. analog TV transmissions to digital by February 17, 2009. Policymakers will consider this budget request for achieving these goals and how NTIA will assist in the conversion process. Additionally, there is a proposal to replace the Census Bureau's Survey of Income and Program Participation with a new data collection system focusing on income and wealth dynamics. The Administration's proposed "Strengthening America's Communities Initiative," reduction of funding levels, creation of a new Regional Development Account within the Economic Development Administration, U.S. trade agencies and PTO fighting intellectual property infringement abroad, enforcement of U.S. trade remedy laws against unfair foreign competition, consolidation of NOAA's budget authority, Congress's review of NOAA satellite programs, proposed terminations of ocean-related programs criticized by the Joint Ocean Commission Initiative, President Bush's "Vision for Space Exploration" reprioritizing NASA programs and potential personnel cuts. The curr_chunk discusses key issues such as Secretary Rice's Transformational Diplomacy vision, reorganization of USAID and State, moving diplomats to countries of critical need, emphasis on language capabilities, and public diplomacy activities. It also covers appropriations for the Department of Justice, established in 1870 to provide counsel and law enforcement for citizens. The Department of Justice (DOJ) represents the federal government in legal proceedings before the Supreme Court, provides legal advice to the President and executive branch, and oversees agencies like United States Attorneys who prosecute criminal offenses, United States Marshals Service for security and prisoner transport, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) for investigating federal crimes and terrorism. The Department of Justice (DOJ) oversees agencies like United States Attorneys, United States Marshals Service, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) for legal proceedings, security, and investigating federal crimes and terrorism. Additionally, it shares jurisdiction with the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) and Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) for drug law violations and enforcement of federal laws related to alcohol, tobacco, firearms, and explosives. The Federal Prison System provides custody and care for federal prisons. The Federal Prison System, under P.L. 107-296, manages the federal prison population, facilities, and boarding of federal prisoners in state and local institutions. The Office of Justice Programs oversees various agencies involved in crime control, with the federal role in criminal justice increasing since the Crime Control Act of 1968. Congress has passed five major crime control bills since 1984, creating new federal crimes and law enforcement assistance programs for state and local governments. For FY2007, Congress appropriated $22.692 billion for discretionary DOJ programs, an increase of $977.9 million over FY2006 appropriations. The Department of Justice's Strategic Plan for FY2003-2008 outlined goals to prevent terrorism, enforce federal laws, prevent crime, and ensure the fair operation of the justice system. The FY2007 budget request included $21.494 billion in spending, representing a decrease of $220 million. The FY2007 budget request included $21.494 billion in spending, with increased funding for preventing terrorism and domestic security. Funding for reducing crime and violence was also proposed, while support for state and local crime prevention was reduced. The federal justice system would receive increased funding under the President's request. The House and Senate passed bills with increased funding for the Department of Justice, exceeding the Administration's request and FY2006 levels. The enacted funding under P.L. 110-5 was $22.692 billion, an increase of $977.9 million over FY2006 appropriations. The General Administration account includes salaries, expenses, and programs to coordinate DOJ agencies for efficient crime-fighting efforts. The DOJ agencies are coordinated to fight crime efficiently with initiatives like the Joint Automated Booking System and the Automated Biometric Identification System. The President's FY2007 budget proposed increased funding for General Administration, including the Attorney General's office, fingerprint identification systems integration, and narrowband communications. Additionally, funding was proposed for the Justice Information Sharing Technology initiative, Narrowband Communications, and the Office of the Detention Trustee. The FY2007 budget proposed $115.5 million for the Attorney General and DOJ senior policy-level offices, excluding funding for the Office of Intelligence and Policy Review. The Administration requested $15.9 million for the National Drug Intelligence Center. The House bill allocated $1.942 billion for General Administration, while the Senate recommended $1.859 million. Salaries and Expenses were set at $35.4 million in the House bill and $41.1 million in the Senate recommendation. JIST funding was $125 million in the House bill and $100 million in the Senate recommendation. The House bill and Senate committee recommended funding amounts for various departments in FY2007. The Office of the Detention Trustee received $1.331 billion from the House and $1.332 billion from the Senate, matching the Administration's request. The Office of the Inspector General is responsible for oversight. The Office of the Inspector General (OIG) oversees DOJ programs, detects waste, fraud, and abuse, and investigates misconduct. The FY2007 budget proposed $70.558 million for the OIG, with the House, Senate, and CR including similar amounts. The U.S. Parole Commission handles parole requests for federal prisoners, with the FY2007 budget requesting $11.951 million, slightly lower than the House and Senate proposals. The FY2007 budget proposed $11.5 million for the Parole Commission, slightly lower than the House and Senate proposals. The Legal Activities account includes subaccounts for various legal activities, with the Administration's budget request totaling $3.446 billion for FY2007. The General Legal Activities account funds the Solicitor General's supervision of the department's conduct in proceedings before the Supreme Court and several departmental divisions. The Administration's FY2007 budget request included $684.3 million for legal activities, an increase of $30.8 million from FY2006. The U.S. Attorneys and U.S. Marshals Service operate in all federal judicial districts, with the U.S. Attorneys prosecuting criminal cases and representing the government in civil actions. The FY2007 request for the U.S. Attorneys Office was $1.664 billion, an increase of $64.8 million from FY2006. The House bill proposed the same amount, while the Senate proposed $1.646 billion. The U.S. Attorneys Office and U.S. Marshals Service are key legal entities in federal judicial districts. The FY2007 budget included $1.646 billion for the U.S. Attorneys and $825.9 million for the Marshals Service. The House proposed $825.9 million, while the Senate proposed $856.0 million for the Marshals. The CR allocated $814.8 million for the Marshals in FY2007. Other legal activities included the Community Relations Service, Independent Counsel, U.S. Trustee Fund, and Asset Forfeiture program. The FY2007 budget allocated $298.2 million for the Asset Forfeiture program, $10.178 million for the Community Relations Service, and $21.211 million for the Assets Forfeiture Fund. The Interagency Law Enforcement account reimburses departmental agencies for their participation in the Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Force program, which aims to disrupt major narcotics-trafficking organizations. Federal agencies like the DEA, FBI, and ATF participate in OCDETF. The Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Force (OCDETF) involves various federal agencies like the DEA, FBI, ATF, U.S. Marshals Service, and others, along with state and local law enforcement. The FY2007 budget allocated $706.1 million for OCDETF, with $208 million for relocating High Intensity Drug Trafficking Areas (HIDTAs). The House bill appropriated $483.2 million for OCDETF in FY2006. The House bill proposed funding of $498.5 million for OCDETF in FY2007, $14.9 million less than the Administration's request. The Senate recommended $388.0 million for the program. The FBI's FY2007 funding request aimed at preventing terrorism and other criminal activities, with a proposed increase of $302.4 million over FY2006 appropriations. The FBI aims to enhance its capabilities in preventing terrorist attacks, disrupting terrorist financing, and investigating and prosecuting those responsible for terrorist acts. The President's FY2007 budget proposed a $48 million increase in funding for counterintelligence and national security. The House bill allocated $6.043 billion for the FBI, including $80.4 million for construction, while the Senate recommended $5.975 billion, with $120.7 million for construction expenses. The CR included total FBI appropriations of $6.014 billion for FY2007, with $5.962 billion specified for salaries and expenses, and $51.4 million for construction. The Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) leads efforts to combat the illicit supply and abuse of narcotics and drugs. The DEA, in collaboration with OCDETF, dismantled 119 drug trafficking organizations and disrupted 208 others in FY2005. The FY2007 budget proposed $1.736 billion for DEA, with the House proposing $1.752 billion and the Senate $1.724 billion. The ATF enforces laws on alcohol, tobacco, firearms, and explosives, with a proposed budget of $860.1 million for FY2007, a decrease from the previous year. The Administration proposed additional funding of $120 million for ATF in FY2007 to be collected from user fees related to explosives. The President's budget aimed to centralize ATF's resources into the Project Safe Neighborhoods (PSN) initiative, which coordinates federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies to address gun crime through prevention, deterrence, and prosecution. Programs like Project Childsafe from OJP would be integrated into PSN to combat crime and violence in high-risk neighborhoods. Childsafe distributes free gun safety kits; Project Sentry supports prosecution of crimes involving misuse of firearms; Gang Technical Assistance Program aids in disrupting criminal gang activity; Weed and Seed program promotes community-based crime control strategies; National Stalker and Domestic Violence Database assists in law enforcement efforts against stalking and domestic violence; National Criminal History Improvement Program sponsors efforts to improve criminal history records for investigations and background checks. The Administration's FY2007 budget proposed funding for the PSN program and ATF's Violent Crime Impact Teams. The House bill provided $950.1 million, and the Senate recommended $985.0 million for ATF funding in FY2007. The Federal Prison System is administered by the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) and maintains penal institutions nationwide. The Administration requested almost $5.107 billion in FY2007 funding for the Federal Prison System, estimating an increase in the federal prison population to 203,880 by 2007. The Bureau of Prisons (BOP) provides substance abuse treatment for eligible inmates, with a growing percentage of federal inmates having a substance abuse disorder. The House and Senate proposed different funding amounts for the Bureau of Prisons in FY2007, with the final CR including $5.407 billion total funding. The Office of Justice Programs manages various justice-related agencies and grant programs, with the Administration requesting a reduced budget of $1.201 billion for FY2007. The House bill provided $2.376 billion in total funding for the Office of Justice Programs. The House bill allocated $2.376 billion in total funding for OJP programs, while the Senate proposed nearly $1.934 billion. The President's FY2007 budget aimed to eliminate funding for several OJP programs, including Byrne JAG and Discretionary Grants, Indian Country Prison Grants, Tribal Court Grants, and most Juvenile Justice programs. The President's FY2007 budget proposed significant cuts to various criminal justice programs, including the elimination of funding for the State Criminal Alien Assistance Program (SCAAP) and the Secure Our Schools (SOS) program. Additionally, funding for the Bulletproof Vests program and the Prison Rape Prevention and Prosecution Program would have been drastically reduced. On the other hand, funding for the Southwest Border Prosecution Initiative was set to increase. The FY2007 budget proposed cuts to criminal justice programs, including eliminating funding for SCAAP and SOS. However, funding for the Southwest Border Prosecution Initiative was set to increase, along with the National Stalker and Domestic Violence Database. The Boys and Girls Clubs of America would receive reduced funding. Both the House and Senate proposed funding for programs not included in the Administration's budget request. The House proposed $635.1 million for JAG grants, while the Senate proposed $555.1 million. The House did not include funding for Byrne Discretionary Grants, but the Senate proposed $120 million. The House proposed $49.3 million for the Weed and Seed program, while the Senate proposed $40 million, reflecting a $9.3 million reduction. The CR included $1.184 billion for law enforcement assistance, including JAG grants and other programs. The Administration's FY2007 request proposed $102.1 million for the COPS program with a rescission of $127.5 million. The President's budget proposal included changes to COPS programs, such as combining some with other OJP programs and transferring them to the Justice Assistance account. Funding for COPS Interoperability and Technology Grants would be eliminated, while the Meth Hot Spots program would see a decrease in funding. The House and Senate proposed different funding levels for the COPS program in FY2007. The Senate proposed funding of $537.6 million for various programs including Bullet Proof Vest, Meth Hot Spots, and COPS technology grants. The House proposed lower funding amounts for these programs. The CR included $541.7 million for COPS in FY2007, with a rescission of up to $109 million from prior year balances. The Justice Assistance account funds OJP bureaus and offices, including the National Institute of Justice and Bureau of Justice Statistics. The Administration's FY2007 budget requested $1.098 billion for Justice Assistance, with the House and Senate proposing $223.6 million and $172 million respectively. The CR allocated $237.7 million for Justice Assistance, rejecting the President's proposal to realign OJP grant programs. The proposed realignment aimed at improving the Criminal Justice System, with $377.2 million requested, including $9.8 million for the Bulletproof Vest Partnership. In FY2007, funding was allocated for various programs including $59.5 million for Boys and Girls Clubs, $165.8 million for the PSN program, $39.7 million for the Regional Information Sharing System, $29.8 million for the Southwest Border Project, $14.9 million for Faith-Based Prisoner Re-entry Initiative, and $1.9 million for Prison Rape Prevention & Prosecution. The House proposed $32 million for Bulletproof Vest program, $75 million for Boys and Girls Clubs, and $415 million for SCAAP, while the Senate recommended $20 million, $85 million, and $100 million respectively. The House allocated $54.8 million for the PSN program. In FY2007, the House bill provided $54.8 million for the PSN program, while the Senate recommended $30 million. The Administration's budget requested $116 million for Research, Development, Evaluation, and Statistics, with $59.8 million for criminal justice statistics and $56.2 million for research projects. The Technology for Crime Identification program proposed $238.2 million in funding, including $175.6 million for DNA analysis. Both the House and Senate bills aimed to fund DNA backlog grants at almost $175.6 million for FY2007, a significant increase over previous levels. In FY2007, the Administration requested almost $175.9 million for strengthening the juvenile justice system, including funding for state and local programs, juvenile delinquency block grants, demonstration projects, and research. The House and Senate proposed funding juvenile justice programs at $285.7 million and $300.2 million respectively, with allocations for formula grants, discretionary grants, and accountability incentive block grants. The CR provided funding of $326 million for FY2007 Juvenile Justice programs, including $49.4 million for Juvenile Accountability Incentive Block Grants and $50 million from the Senate. The Administration's FY2007 budget request for Substance Abuse Demand Reduction included $79.9 million, with $69.2 million for Drug Courts and $10.7 million for the Cannabis Eradication Grant program. The House proposed $40 million for Drug Courts, while the Senate recommended $15 million. For the RSAT program, the House bill included $5 million and the Senate bill included $2 million. Neither bill included funding for the Cannabis Eradication grant program. The Administration's budget request for services for Victims of Crime (VOC) within the Justice Assistance account included $109.4 million. This amount would fund programs authorized under the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) and Victims of Child Abuse Act, including the Missing Child program, Victim Notification System, legal counsel, support services for victims, improving investigation and prosecution of child abuse, National Sex Offender Public Registry, and victims of trafficking. The President's FY2007 budget proposed a $625 million cap for the Crime Victims Fund and a proposal to rescind $1.255 billion from balances in the fund. The Crime Victims Fund cap for FY2007 was set at $625 million in the House and Senate bills, with no provisions to rescind the fund balance. The Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) was allocated $347 million in the Administration's FY2007 budget request, including funding for programs like CASA and Child Abuse Training. The House bill included $418.3 million for VAWA programs, while the Senate recommended $390 million. The CR provided $382.5 million for VAWA programs. Additionally, there were allocations for Community Oriented Policing Services, Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant Program, Gun Control, Hate Crime Legislation, and Terrorist Screening. Title II includes appropriations for the Department of Commerce and related agencies, with origins dating back to 1903. The Department of Commerce was established in 1913 with various responsibilities focused on promoting U.S. business, improving technological competitiveness, encouraging economic development, fostering environmental stewardship, and providing statistical information on the economy and population. Agencies within the department, such as the Economic Development Administration and Minority Business Development Agency, carry out these missions. The Department of Commerce promotes private and public sector investment in minority businesses. The Bureau of the Census collects economic, demographic, and social data. Economic and Statistical Analysis Programs provide timely information on the economy and analytical support. The International Trade Administration develops export potential and improves trade performance. The Bureau of Industry and Security enforces export laws. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration provides scientific expertise for safety. The Department of Commerce includes agencies like NOAA, PTO, Technology Administration, and NIST, which provide expertise in marine and air navigation, coastal resource health assessment, environmental monitoring, patent and trademark approvals, technology policy advocacy, and industry technology development support. The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) advises the President on communications policy, manages radio frequency spectrum use, and conducts research in telecommunications. The President's FY2007 budget requested $6.18 billion for the Commerce Department, a decrease from the previous year. The House bill proposed further cuts to the Department's budget, particularly in accounts for NOAA, EDA, Census, and departmental management. The President's FY2007 budget requested $98.5 million for Departmental Management, including $57 million for salaries and expenses, $22.53 million for the Office of Inspector General, and $18 million for renovation of the Department's headquarters. The enacted funding level for Departmental Management in FY2007 was $47 million for salaries and expenses and $22 million for the IG. The requested budget for salaries and expenses would have been a 20% increase from FY2006, while the IG budget would have seen a slight increase. The House bill provided $30.1 million for salaries and expenses, $26.9 million less than requested and $16.8 million less than the FY2006 appropriation. The Senate committee recommended $52.1 million for salaries and expenses, including $5.9 million for blast protection windows in the Hoover Building. The Senate also allocated $22.5 million for the IG, bringing the total departmental management account to $74.6 million. The International Trade Administration (ITA) oversees trade agreements, trade remedies, and supports trade negotiations. It is divided into four policy units and an Executive and Administrative Directorate with a staff of 2,217 in FY2006. The funding level for ITA in FY2007 was $393.8 million, the same as FY2006. The President's FY2007 request was $408.8 million, with a $14.9 million increase. The House recommended $429.8 million for ITA in FY2007. In FY2007, the House Appropriations Committee recommended a net appropriation of $416.8 million for the International Trade Administration (ITA), $8 million more than the budget request. The Committee also provided additional funding for overseas ongoing operations and increased exports of environmental technologies. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended a net appropriation of $413.8 million for ITA, $5 million above the budget request. The Manufacturing and Services Unit (MSU) promotes the competitiveness of the U.S. manufacturing sector under the President's Manufacturing Initiative of March 2003. The Manufacturing and Services Unit (MSU) promotes the competitiveness of the U.S. manufacturing sector under the President's Manufacturing Initiative of March 2003. Congress transferred trade promotion activities to the new Trade Promotion Unit. The FY2006 appropriation provided $47 million for MSU. The President requested $47.3 million for FY2007. The MAC monitors foreign country compliance with trade agreements and informs U.S. firms of foreign business practices. The FY2006 appropriation provided $43 million for MAC. The President requested $39.3 million for FY2007. The House recommendation for MAC was $40.8 million. The Senate recommendation for MAC was the same as the budget request. IA administers the trade remedy laws of the United States. In FY2006, IA received $59 million in appropriations. The Administration requested $59.4 million for IA in FY2007. The House recommended $61.4 million, while the Senate recommended $59.4 million. The TP/FCS program received $227 million in FY2006 and the Administration requested $237.3 million for FY2007. The House recommended $249.8 million and the Senate recommended $242.3 million for TP/FCS. The Senate recommended $242.3 million for TP/FCS, $5 million above the budget request. USTR, responsible for U.S. international trade policies, had a FY2007 request of $42.2 million, $2 million less than FY2006. The House approved $46.2 million, with $2 million for trade agreements with China. The Senate recommended $42.2 million for USTR, matching the Administration's request. The funding level for USTR in FY2007 was $44.2 million, the same as FY2006. The USTR's budget for FY2007 remained at $44.2 million, the same as in FY2006. The agency is responsible for advancing U.S. interests at the WTO and negotiating FTAs. The Administration concluded FTAs with several countries and is in ongoing negotiations with others. The USTR also obtained congressional approval for FTAs with Bahrain, the Dominican Republic, Central American countries, and Oman in 2006. The Office had 229 full-time employees in FY2006. The ITC advises the President and Congress on the impact of U.S. foreign economic policies on U.S. industries. The Import Administration Unit of ITA administers U.S. trade remedy laws with six commissioners appointed by the President. In FY2007, ITC requested $64.2 million, a $2 million increase from FY2006. The House approved $62.6 million, the Senate recommended $64.2 million, and the funding level enacted was $62.0 million. The President's FY2007 request for the Bureau of Industry and Security was $78.6 million, a 3.4% increase. The Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) received a funding increase to $78.6 million in FY2007. BIS administers export controls on dual-use goods and technology, cooperates with other nations on export control policy, and assists the U.S. business community with compliance. It also administers U.S. anti-boycott statutes and monitors the U.S. defense industrial base. The agency had 415 full-time employees in FY2006, and the authorization for its activities last expired in August 2001. President Bush invoked the International Economic Emergency Powers Act to continue controls under the Export Administration Regulations. BIS's FY2007 funding request was divided between licensing, enforcement, and policy coordination, with a significant amount for Chemical Weapons Convention enforcement. The House recommended $76.8 million, while the Senate Appropriations Committee supported the President's request of $78.6 million. The Administration's budget request for FY2007 included a proposal to reshape federal economic and community development programs, with $327.2 million allocated for EDA activities. This funding included $257 million for the new Regional Development Account program, $27 million for planning grants, $13 million for trade adjustment assistance, and $29 million for salaries and expenses. This marked an increase from the previous year's appropriation of $280.4 million. The Administration's FY2007 budget proposal included $327.2 million for EDA activities, with funding for the Regional Development Account program, planning grants, trade adjustment assistance, and salaries. The proposal aimed to consolidate 18 community and economic development programs into the Strengthening America's Communities Initiative, but Congress rejected this and funded all 18 programs for FY2006. The Administration's FY2007 budget proposed a revamped SACI proposal, funding only two programs - CDBG and RDA, with a total of $3.360 billion. The proposal included new goals, performance measures, and reforms for the programs. The FY2007 budget proposed a revamped SACI proposal, funding only CDBG and RDA programs with $3.360 billion. The RDA would consolidate four EDA programs into one account, awarding funds competitively for regional development activities. H.R. 5672 recommended $260.4 million for EDA activities in FY2007. The proposed funding for EDA activities in FY2007 included $12.8 million for trade adjustment assistance, $26 million for planning grants, and $29.7 million for salary and expenses. This was $20 million less than appropriated for FY2006 and recommended by the Senate, and $66.8 million less than the Administration's request. The House version of H.R. 5672 would reduce funding for public works projects by $19 million compared to FY2006, with smaller reductions in economic adjustment assistance, trade adjustment assistance, and technical assistance. The bill also directed the EDA to continue funding the planning grant program for economic districts. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended an appropriation of $280.4 million for EDA program activities and salaries and expenses in response to concerns about potential office closures. This amount was $47 million less than requested by the Administration and $20 million more than recommended by the House. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $280.4 million for EDA program activities and salaries and expenses, $47 million less than requested by the Administration. The bill included funding for various programs such as pubic works, economic adjustment grants, technical assistance, trade adjustment assistance, planning grants, research grants, and salaries and expenses. The report rejected the Administration's request for program consolidation and expressed concern about fund distribution among EDA's regional offices. The EDA program funds are to be allocated among the agency's six regional offices within 30 days. The MBDA coordinates federal minority business programs with a budget of $29.6 million for FY2007, approved by the Senate Appropriations Committee and the House. The funding level for the MBDA in FY2007 is $30 million, the same as FY2006. The Administration requested $30.7 million for FY2006, but Congress approved $30.0 million. The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) received $29.6 million in funding for FY2006, reduced from the requested $30.7 million due to a rescission. NTIA serves as the executive branch's advisory office on telecommunications and information technology issues, supporting access to services, international market openings, research grants, and digital transmission assistance for nonprofit organizations. NTIA manages radio frequency spectrum use domestically and internationally. For FY2007, NTIA received funding at FY2006 levels through a continuing resolution. The NTIA budget for FY2006 was $39.6 million, with two main components: Salaries and Expenses received $17.8 million, mainly for managing information and telecommunications policies, and the Public Telecommunications and Facilities Program (PTFPC) received $21.7 million. The Bush Administration requested $18.5 million for Salaries and Expenses in FY2008. The Bush Administration sought to end funding for the Public Telecommunications and Facilities Program (PTFPC) in its FY2008 budget request. Another program requested was the Digital Transition and Safety Public Fund, funded by receipts from spectrum license auctions, set at $45 million in FY2007. This fund would support a digital-analog converter box program and public safety grants for interoperable communications. The FY2007 CR includes funding for public safety interoperable communications grants, New York City's 9/11 digital transition, assistance for low-power television stations, a national alert and tsunami warning program, and funding to enhance a national alert system. However, complete funding for these functions has not been determined yet. The President's budget did not request funding for the National Technical Information Service for FY2007. The House of Representatives also did not appropriate any funding. The National Technical Information Service (NTIS) did not receive funding for FY2007 from the House of Representatives, Senate Committee on Appropriations, or the continuing resolution (P.L. 110-5). NTIS will continue to draw funding from its Revolving Fund. NTIS achieved a positive net income of $1.92 million for FY2006 due to efforts to develop new products and limit spending. NTIS is part of the Technology Administration at the Department of Commerce. The National Technical Information Service (NTIS) was established within the Department of Commerce in 1970, with origins dating back to World War II. It serves as the central source for the sale of scientific, technical, engineering, and business information for the U.S. government and international sources, supporting economic growth and job creation. The NTIS supports economic growth and job creation by providing access to government information products. It offers fee-based services to federal agencies, including distribution of information products, web development, and custom research services. The growth of electronic publishing has impacted NTIS sales, as more documents are available online for free from other sources. The NTIS provides information services that may overlap with private sector companies. They maintain a permanent repository of information, including budget requests for discretionary spending by the Bureau of the Census. The FY2007 budget request for the Bureau of the Census was $66 million higher than the FY2006 enacted amount. This increase was mainly for preparations for the 2010 census, including the American Community Survey.
